section.title: SRv6 Security Problem
section.t: SRv6 relies in its architecture on the concept of limited domain which is too vague a concept to form a solid security base.
Limited domains that fail can open and will invariably leak. (so far this is nonsense)
As per RFC8402 SRv6 that leaks into a domain is a security violation (section 8).
Solution is to build a limited domain that is properly trusted/closed.
Exmaples of fail closed protocols: mpls/clns/llpd/bier

section.title: Characteristics of a Fail-Closed Protocol Domain
section.t: A fail closed protocol domain is determined by following properties:

dl.dt: Processing of the protocol packet on an interface requires explicit configuration with default drop behavior.
Leaking of protocol packets beyond the boundary of fail-closed domain requires explicit config.
Fail closed protocols must be identifiable by their top level (e.g. link layer) encoding.
Classification of the protocol must be deterministic.
Confining the protocol to the trusted domaim must not require complex processing in either HW or software.
Boundary of a trusted domain consists of a set of interfaces that exhibit default behavior.
